titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the George H. Seeley Papers and Photographs
titlestmt.author: by Matthew Daniel Mason

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday January 23, 2019 at 04:41

did.unittitle: George H. Seeley papers and photographs

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: This collection consists chiefly of papers and photographs created and collected by George H. Seeley that document his photographic career, as well as his later life and family spanning from 1900 to 1975. The collection includes glass plate negatives used by Seeley to create his professional photographs. Photographic prints in the collection are predominantly work prints created by Seeley. There are also film negatives that document his later life and family, as well as the landscape around Stockbridge and at Cape Cod.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Marion Cady Davis Byron, 1975.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 8-17 (glass negatives): Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Boxes 19-21 (glass transparencies): Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
Boxes 22-23 (film negatives): Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The George H. Seeley Papers and Photographs is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: George H. Seeley Papers and Photographs. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid is based on an inventory of the collectioncreated by library staff in the 1970s. The collection was further processed in 2011, when it was arranged into the present series structure and rehoused into acid-free boxes.
Former call number: Uncat Za Ms 350.

bioghist.head: George H. Seeley (1880-1955)
bioghist.p: George Henry Seeley (1880-1955) was a photographer. He was a lifetime resident of Stockbridge, Massachusetts and supervisor of the art instruction for local schools, as well as an amateur ornithologist. As a photographer, Seeley was a leading member of the Photo-Secession movement along with Alfred Stieglitz, Clarence White, and others. Related to this work, he wrote articles about photography and published his photographs in photographic journals, including Camera Work , as well as exhibiting his images around the world. Seeley frequently used his sisters, May Elizabeth Seeley (born 1878), Lilian R. Seeley (born 1884), and Laura S. Seeley (1888-1979), as models for his photographs. His photography emphasizes soft focuses and subtle tonality. Seeley is also known for his landscape photography of winters in New England and Cape Cod beachscapes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection consists chiefly of papers and photographs created and collected by George H. Seeley that document his photographic career, as well as his later life and family spanning from 1900 to 1975.

A strength of the collection is the glass plate negatives used by Seeley to create his professional photographs. Photographic prints in the collection are predominantly work prints created by Seeley. There are film negatives that document his later life and family, as well as the landscape around Stockbridge and at Cape Cod.

A scrapbook in the collection, 1900-1915, includes correspondence with Alfred Stieglitz and Clarence White, as well as Curtis Bell, Alvin Langdon Coburn, Wendell G. Corthell, Daniel Chester French, Spencer Kellogg, Jr., John Nilsen Laurvik, Philip P. Sharples, and Edward Steichen. There is also loose correspondence with many of the same people, circa 1900-1930, as well as John Burroughs, Adolph de Meyer, Edward R. Dickson, and Augustus Thibaudeau. Writings in the collection include a set of index cards with notes relating to his photography and a notebook with entries about birds, as well as drafts by Laura Seeley about art photography and her brother. Realia in the collection consists of medals and awards for his photography, 1905-1930, as well as a register for an exhibit of Seeley's photographs in New York City, circa 1915-1918.

A small quantity of correspondence in the collection documents communication between his sister, Laura Seeley and Robert M. Doty of the George Eastman House, as well as with staff at the Yale University Library, circa 1960.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Papers, 1900-1975. II. Photographs, 1900-1950. III. Negatives and Glass Transparencies, circa 1900-1940.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into three subseries: Correspondence, Writings, and Other Papers and Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of correspondence written to Seeley, as well as examples of his writing and collected material. A scrapbook in in the subseries Other Papers and Material also includes correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Scrapbook compiled by Seeley that includes correspondence, exhibition catalogs, tear sheets, and newspaper clippings.

Scattered correspondence, 1904-1913, includes letters from Curtis Bell, Alvin Langdon Coburn, Wendell G. Corthell, Daniel Chester French, Spencer Kellogg, Jr., John Nilsen Laurvik, Philip P. Sharples, Edward Steichen, Alfred Stieglitz, and Clarence H. White, as well as the Société de photographie de Marseille. There is also a poem dedicated to Seeley by Frederick Henry Koch in 1909.

The scrapbook includes catalogs and newspaper clippings related to exhibitions of Seeley's photographs, 1905-1915. These include shows at the Albright Art Gallery, Galleries of the Art Association of Montreal, Montross Gallery, National Arts Club, Photographic Society of Philadelphia, Photo-Succession Galleries, Print Gallery, and Utica Public Library, as well as shows at his home. A catalog for an exhibition at the Free Public Library of Newark in 1911 is accompanied by photographs of the show.

Tear sheets of photographic reproductions and articles about Seeley, 1900-1914, derive from several publications, including Academy Notes , American Photography , The Camera , The Craftsman , The International Studio , Photo Era , The Photographer , Western Camera Notes , and Wilson's Photographic Magazine .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into three subseries: Photographic Prints, Photograph Album, and Family Photographs and Photographs by Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of artistic and family photographs created by Seeley. The photographic prints may derive from negatives in Series III, but no effort was made to match prints to negatives during processing the collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chiefly work platinum prints of art photographs created Seeley. Many of the images depict his sisters, May Elizabeth Seeley, Lilian R. Seeley, and Laura S. Seeley as allegorical figures. A portion of the prints depict male figures, including several portraits of an African American man. Landscape views in the subseries depict farms, ponds, streams, and woodland scenes. There is also a small quantity of still lifes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Album with contact gelatin silver prints from glass plate negatives. Images principally consist of portraits of Seeley's sisters, as well as landscape views and still lifes.

did.unittitle: Family Photographs and Photographs by Others

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries principally includes informal family photographs that depict Seeley, his sisters, and his extended family, including his brother-in-law, Winthrop Isham Davis (1870-1957), and niece, Marion Cady Davis Byron (1910-1988).

Photographs by other photographers include a portrait of Frederick H. Koch created in 1908 by John H. Lorenz of Boston, Massachusetts, and inscribed to Seeley by Koch; a view of the rostrum on Laurel Hill in Stockbridge, Massachusetts, by F. S. Hyman, Jr., circa 1945; and a studio portrait of an unidentified group of men and women, circa 1905.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into three subseries: Glass Negatives, Glass Transparencies, and Film Negatives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series chiefly consists of artistic and family photographs created by Seeley. The negatives may be the source for photographic prints in Series II, but no effort was made to match prints to negatives during processing the collection.

Many of the images on the glass negatives and transparencies depict his sisters, May Elizabeth Seeley, Lilian R. Seeley, and Laura S. Seeley as allegorical figures, as well as images of of male figures. Landscape views in the subseries depict farms, ponds, streams, woodland scenes, and beachscapes. There is also a number of still lifes.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A sample set of two boxes that originally housed the glass negatives.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nitrate film negatives of photographic images created by Seeley that chiefly document natural and built landscapes, probably surrounding Stockbridge and Cape Cod, Massachusetts, as well as informal images of his family and animals, including cows, ducks, and wild birds.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
